Rape and sexual assault are a huge problem in India. Now there may be a new 
technology that can help women, if they find themselves in a dangerous 
situation. Ana Kasparian and John Iadarola, hosts of The Young Turks, break 
it down. Tell us what you think in the comment section below.

“All mobile phones sold in India from January 2017 must have a panic button 
enabling the user to call for help, the government has said, amid concern 
for women's safety after a series of violent crimes in recent years.

From January 2018, mobile phones must also have a built-in global 
positioning system (GPS), the ministry of communications and technology 
said in a statement.

"Technology is solely meant to make human life better and what better (use) 
than ... for the security of women," said the statement, released late on 
Monday.

Keeping a finger pressed on number 5 or 9 on the new mobile phones should 
trigger an emergency call, the ministry said. With smartphones, an 
emergency call must be triggered when the power button is pressed three 
times in quick succession, it said. It did not give further details.”

the rest of what you have to say and to get upset at you for being 
disingenuous. Rape is a horrible thing and so you shouldn't lie about it or 
trivialize it to the point where you say that 20% of women will get raped.

+michaelal20 The only argument you have is that rape is on the down, but 
that does not mean it isn't a problem.

In a hypothetical if 10 million people died per year from 1970 but by 2010 
it was down to 5 million, that is a downward spiral, but that is still a 
high number.

Those numbers are for arguments sake, don't take it as if to say, 'well 
rape doesn't occur in the millions so it isn't a problem'. Tens of 
thousands of rapes per year is a horrible statistic for any first world 
country. On top of that a massive portion of rape goes unreported.

+michaelal20 I beg to differ, it's ironic that it is always the people who 
don't know about rape that claim rape isn't a problem because none of their 
friend's or families have been raped and it never gets publicised because 
either the women does not come forward or because it is far too hard to 
prove.

It has been repeatedly proven and stated that a massive majority of rape 
cases are under reported, and the ones that are reported in the tens of 
thousands. There is a problem with rape, whether you like it or not.

America doesn't have a rape culture. Stop living in a bubble. Real problems 
are in 3rd world countries
